title: Which is more correct, “We had held a few concerts in that hall before” or “We have held a few concerts in that hall before”? - Quora

response.answer_text: Both are correct but they refer to different circumstances. (The timelines are different.) “We have held a few concerts in that hall before” is more likely to be applicable in most situations and simply means that the hall in question has been used by us, at unspecified times in the past, for concerts. (The verb tense here is the Present perfect.) “We had held a few concerts in that hall before” on the other hand refers to a situation in which you were holding - or intending to hold - a concert in the past and are noting that the same venue (the hall) was used on earlier occasions for the same purpose. (This is an example of the Past Perfect which is used to relate two different events, both in the past, one occurring before the other.)

It depends on the context. If you’re talking about time in the past up until the present moment, you would say We have held a few concerts… This would be the more usual form. If you’re talking about time in the past up until some other moment in the past, you would say We had held… For example, We decided not to use that hall for the concert because we had held a few concerts in that hall before. In this example, you’re talking about time in the past before you decided.
